item.title: How to Watch Apple’s iPhone 17 Announcement, and What to Expect

review.headline_rewrite: How to Watch Apple’s iPhone 17 Announcement, and What to Expect
bullets: Apple’s latest product launch event is happening on September 9.
We’ll likely see a full line of iPhones 17, including the base model, the Pro models, and a brand-new ultra-thin version called the iPhone Air.
We are also expecting new Apple Watches and new AirPods.
All of these devices will surely have some sort of AI-enabled capabilities.
Just know that Apple always stays tight-lipped in the lead-up to its launch events, so the information we’re providing here is speculative.

Air Born
The biggest news of the event might just be about one of the lightest gadgets in the lineup.

item.title: The 21 Best Movies on Amazon Prime Right Now (September 2025)

review.headline_rewrite: The 21 Best Movies on Amazon Prime Right Now (September 2025)
bullets:
Air
Sure, nowadays Michael Jordan is a bona fide sports god, and Nike Air Jordans are still arguably the cool sneaker—but that wasn’t the case back in 1984.
We all know how that panned out, so thankfully Air is more than a two-hour advert for gym shoes.
In an age of franchises and endless blockbusters, Air is the sort of character-focused film that rarely gets made anymore, and is all the more enjoyable for it.

American Fiction
Heads of State
Grumpy British prime minister Sam Clarke (Idris Elba) and action-movie star turned US President Will Derringer (John Cena) can't stand each other—so teaming up to survive after Air Force One is shot down over the Belarusian wilderness is going to put a real strain on the Special Relationship.

Deep Cover
The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the 8th Dimension
One of the absolute wildest films you've probably never seen, 1984's The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai is … almost impossible to describe.
Buckaroo Banzai—a super-genius physicist, skilled neurosurgeon, high-flying test pilot, and beloved rock star—the film follows his battle with the evil Dr.

item.title: Silksong, smacking sticks and other new indie games worth checking out

review.headline_rewrite: Silksong, smacking sticks and other new indie games worth checking out
bullets: You have until 11AM ET on September 11 to claim the classic puzzle game.
Again, you'll have a week to claim those.
Games you claim here are yours to keep forever, even if you don't maintain your Prime membership.
Amazon offered up a particularly tasty one this week in the shape of Into The Breach, a hugely acclaimed strategy game, but there are plenty of others to check out.
After a seven-year wait, Silksong is by some distance the highest-profile indie game to arrive in 2025 so far.
Perhaps if we start mentioning another long-awaited game — say, Kingdom Hearts 4?

item.title: Technology Sep 6, 2025 Want Intel as chip partner but…: Qualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon why company will stick with TSMC

review.headline_rewrite: Technology Sep 6, 2025 Want Intel as chip partner but…: Qualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon why company will stick with TSMC
bullets: Qualcomm CEO Cristiano Amon stated that Intel's current chip production technology isn't advanced enough for Qualcomm to consider it a supplier.

In an interview on Bloomberg Television's "Bloomberg Tech" on Friday (September 5), Amon said that while Qualcomm would like to use Intel for manufacturing, it will stick with its current partners, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.

We would like Intel to be an option,â Amon said, explaining that if Intel is able to advance its manufacturing techniques to produce more efficient chips, then Qualcomm would consider becoming a customer.
This move is aimed at securing growth that doesn't depend on the smartphone market.
The company announced a new self-driving product that will be used in BMW's upcoming iX3 sports utility vehicle.
Amon said the system can be scaled from basic driver assistance to a full-on autonomous mode without draining the car's battery.

‘We have apologised to…’: Australia’s biggest bank decides not to replace human jobs with AI
The Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) has backtracked on its plan to eliminate 45 customer service positions due to AI implementation, following pressure from the Finance Sector Union.
CBA admitted its assessment was flawed and offered affected employees options to remain, apply elsewhere, or exit.
